Author: Jushara_iiskra

Comment: I'm on Armour Thyroid because synthetic thyroid medication messes with my liver. I was on synthroid for 6 months and my liver enzymes were through the roof and I was starting to jaundice. and it also felt like someone was pulling fishing line through my nerves. I was switched to the Armour Thyroid and the issue went away. it was tested a few years later when a new Endocrinologist didn't believe it was the cause, switched me back and within 2 weeks my liver enzymes were elevated again.  I've been wanting to try cytomel(liothyronine) but since the armour was working my endocrinologist didn't want to mess with it. The generics work but their quality control sucks so the dosing is inaccurate. but generics are what would get screwed the most out of this.  My thyroid has been absolutely F'ed my entire life. I went into a medexema coma at 19 (For the curious it's technically "not" A coma since you CAN be roused to consciousness but it is more like sleeping 20 hours a day and having multiple organ failure)  It's technically not the most expensive medication ever, it's "only" about $140 a month for me with a coupon. but I'm not exactly living a life of financial affluence. my concern isn't just the price but also getting access to the medication since I doubt supplies will last if generics skyrocket in price. The FDA has already been trying to move everyone to synthetics the only reason they keep delaying banning desiccated thyroid is because some people still have issues with the synthetics and noone has come up with a more tolerated t4 supplement
Author: Jushara_iiskra

Comment: [Aus PBS overview](https://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/Parliamentary_departments/Parliamentary_Library/Research/Quick_Guides/2021-22/ThePharmaceuticalBenefitsScheme#heading_1126b7edd76e4970874316addf6850fb)  The wording is a little tricky to get your head around! This example of Cosentyx shows that the original cost of the medication is $1405, but the patient will pay only $31.60 of that. Our government covers the remaining balance. PBS is a life saver and, personally, I could not afford to keep my body alive and thriving without it.
